content:
• Menu app icon > Help > More TRoubleshooting Information
  • under 'Application Basics' - hald way - Profile Folders - click on 'Open Folder'

a new window opens showing the content of your profile name folder

  • Exit Thunderbird now. This is important.
  • click on 'Mail ' folder
  • click on the pop account name folder to see contents

You will see mbox files with same name as folders you normally see in Folder Pane - they do NOT have any extension. These files contain emails. Do NOT delete any of those mbox files.

You should see a load of index files - they have a .msf extension. Delete all the * .msf files.

If you have any folders with a .sbd extension - it means you have some subfolders. Click on those '*.sbd' folders to see contents and delete any files with the .msf extension

When finished Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: gjhowlett80

content: You need to know where the attachment is stored. Different software products store their documents or images in various folders. You can view files by clicking start button and 'File Explorer' should appear as an option. Click that to view all folders. The 'Documents' folder is commonly used, but what you want might be elsewhere.
creator: davidsk

content:
You say: want to add an attachment from my computer

We understand you have created a file which you want to send to someone. What type of file did you create and save - an image file or a MS Word document etc ? Where is that file located? Most people usually save files in 'Documents'; saving to the Desktop is not often used as a location to save a file. The 'Desktop' usually contains a load of icons that are shortcuts to start programs or quick access to commonly used folders.

When you start computer, you probably have to logon to 'User Account' Then the computer opens up and the first thing you will see is the Desktop for your user account.

Did you save the file in a folder on your computer? If yes, what is the name of that folder? or did you really save it onto your Desktop ? Can you see the file you created on your Desktop view?

You say "I click attach and then select desktop but there is nothing there" It will only display the file if you saved the file on the desktop. It will not display the file if you saved it in a folder somewhere else on computer.

You say " if i select other locations then all there is is codes." I'm not sure what you mean by 'all there in codes'. I have no idea what you mean by 'other locations'. Perhaps you clicked on 'This PC' and it's showing the various Drives.

Try looking for your User Account name and then look for the folder where you saved the file - maybe it was called 'Documents'.

That 'Attach Files' window is your standard explorer window whcih allows you to navigate to anywhere on your computer.

In Thunderbird Write window When you click on 'Attach' , a window opens allowing you to locate the file you want to attach. First you have to locate where you saved the file. then select the File click on Open to attach file.

content:
Thank you David and James for your responses, and you are both correct in what you have communicated. However, not long after I posted my question, I worked out what the problems were!

Because I'm using a new operating system (Windows 11 Pro) and a new computer with a larger monitor display, everything appears and works differently. I discovered an "X" up in the right hand corner of my screen which cancels and removes the donation box in the middle of the page, which I had formerly not been able to progress past until I had made a donation.

Regarding the failure to download, I discovered that every time I had clicked on the "Download" button, the start-up file had indeed been downloaded, something like 10 times! However, with my new PC set-up, I was receiving no notification that I had successfully downloaded, or where it was to be found! When I found that I had indeed been downloading the set-up files, I was easily able to go through the "Wizard", and get my Thunderbird Account installed on my new PC! So, all is now good!

Thank you again for the responses to my cry for help, and I'm sorry for any inconveniances I may have caused, due to my neophyte ignorance!

Kind regards,

Chris B.

creator: tcluster

content:
I think I've figured out what the problem is. The bottom line seems to be that if you're using Windows 11, and you put it into SLEEP mode, but you leave Thunderbird active, you'll be unable to log onto your various email accounts, even though you use the correct userids/passwords. I've also found that if you restart Thunderbird in Troubleshooting mode, you'll be able to log on with the correct userids and passwords.

I did a fair amount of research on the difference between sleep mode in Windows 10 and Windows 11. In Windows 10 I never had a problem. There is apparently something called Hibernate mode and you'll read things which say it's often not available on Windows 11 desktop machines (which is what I have - a Dell XPS8950). Nevertheless I tried very hard to activate Hibernate mode on my Windows 11 Pro machine, without success. I called Dell and they basically gave me the same information that I had already read online. None of the procedures worked, usually because the options that the recipe told you to use were unavailable or brought up screens that were completely different.

There was one option that did work, going into Command mode and entering "powercfg/a". It showed that on my machine supposedly Standby (S3), Hibernate, and Fast Startup were available. But when I tried to activate Hibernate mode using another "powercfg" option, it said that I lacked sufficient authority.

I believe Hibernate is the same as S4. There are S options from 1 through 4. I'm guessing that my Windows 10 machine was using S0 because I found something that says it allows fast startup which I did have in Windows 10. It seems clear to me that S3 is the culprit. Whether Thunderbird can be fixed to interrogate the status of the machine before it attempts to retrieve or send email I don't know.

I now make sure that I NEVER leave the machine in Sleep mode with Thunderbird active. To help me with this I've changed it so that Sleep mode will never be activated by the mere passage of time. In practice I've taken to doing a complete shutdown because it was easy to make an icon on the desktop which did this. The only way I know to activate sleep mode is CTL/ALT/DELETE and then click on the option in the lower right corner. Too many steps. It's easier to just shut the machine down.

By the way, on the Dell keyboard for my Windows 10 machine there was a key for sleep mode. This key is not present on my Windows 11 machine, again with a Dell branded keyboard.
creator: tcluster

content: The problem isn't solved. Even though I'm not putting, or allowing, the Windows 11 machine to go into Sleep mode, the problem just recurred. Suddenly Thunderbird lost the passwords for my three mail servers and I had to restart Thunderbird in Troubleshooting mode to enter the passwords. There's a big problem here, I would hope someone might respond. Has no one else encountered this problem with Windows 11? I have Carbonite also, in case that's pertinent. (I didn't have Carbonite when I was on my Windows 10 machine.)
creator: tcluster

content:
re :Suddenly Thunderbird lost the passwords for my three mail servers

Is it possible you have software on computer that is cleaning up files?

Cleanup software is notorious for removing password files, session files etc.

CCleaner, WiseCleaner or even Anti-Virus products can do it.

Advise, if you use any product that can cleanup files then you need to make the Thunderbird profile folder exempt from scanning and cleanup.

I believe Windows 11 has a 'Cleanup Recommendations' - check it is not listing any thunderbird file.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Hello Mr. Toad-Hall,

Thank you for the response. I found some cleanup parameters but nothing that allowed me to control or specify specific files or directories. I have Thunderbird installed on my "D" drive, which is an external drive. There is a small set of files on C:\Users\tclus\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird, but the profiles.ini file points to the folder on the D drive.

Is there a way for me to locate the deficiency or error next time this occurs? My understanding of Troubleshooting mode (the only way I can get out of this problem and successfully re-enter the passwords) is that it deletes unused or old or unnecessary (not sure which) files. Whatever the problem is, it doesn't delete the information about the three email accounts, instead it acts like the password is missing or invalid. It invites me to enter the password, but it immediately responds with another invitation to reenter the password. In other words, it acts like the password I entered is incorrect. I assume there's no file that contains ONLY the passwords - instead I'm guessing there's a file which contains information about the email servers which includes the passwords. Next time this happens I could examine this file. Or is there possibly a trace function I could invoke when the entered password doesn't work?

I have no cleanup programs, nor do I use any of the security programs like Norton or McAfee. I depend upon Windows Defender. I do use Carbonite. Is it possible that if Carbonite is copying a file to the cloud that the file is momentarily unavailable to Thunderbird? Carbonite is the only new feature I've added on the Windows 11 system. Thunderbird was on the same external "D" drive in Windows 10. I put it there to make it easy to switch over to Windows 11.

I'm willing to work with anyone who knows how Thunderbird works to get to the bottom of this most irritating syndrome. I appreciate all help.
creator: tcluster

content:
Troubleshooting mode disables all addons and disables hardware acceleration. See info: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird


  • cert9.db File used for Security certificates. It works together with key4.db.
  • key4.db File used for the Key database. Works together with cert9.db
  • logins.json Stores encrypted passwords, and requires key4.db and cert9.db to work.
  • pkcs11.txt Security module database.

I have come across a few cases in the past when passwords were not neing saved. Old cases when people upgraded to version 60.2.1 and also some more recent upgrades. If someone went from Windows to Linux then it was necessary to delete 'pkcs11.txt'.

The 'pkcs11.txt' file is located in the 'profile name' folder.

Please try this:

  • Exit Thunderbird
  • Access 'profile name' folder
  • Delete the 'pkcs11.txt' file.
  • Start Thunderbird.

A new 'pkcs11.txt' file should auto get created.

Enter passwords at prompt and remember to select the checkbox to 'Remember Passwords' before you click on OK.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Thank you. I saved a copy of the pkcs11.txt file, which in retrospect was a good idea, because when I restarted Thunderbird it did not make a new version of the file. Also, it asked for the password but when I entered it the indicator in the upper left corner kept going back and forth which suggested it was in some kind of loop. I restarted it in Troubleshooting mode and it worked, sort of, even though there was no pkcs11.txt file. I say "sort of" because I didn't keep detailed notes, but I think it worked without my entering a password.

Anyhow, I noticed that the pkcs11.txt file had the file spec for the C drive location, going back to 2018, so I made a copy of pkcs11.txt with that location changed to the new D drive location, and I restarted Thunderbird, NOT in troubleshooting mode, and it works perfectly.

So I believe all I really did was change the file location shown in the pkcs11.txt file to point to its new location. It'll be interesting to see if this eliminates the problem I've been having. To recount, those problems initially seemed to be related to Windows 11 sleep mode, and I stopped using that, but then more recently there was a recurrence of the problem and I know it wasn't related to Windows 11 sleep mode, so I'm not sure what caused it. I have my fingers crossed that the problem won't recur.

I appreciate your help. I'll update this record if anything happens down the line. Meanwhile, if anyone else complains of a problem like mine I'd be most interested to know what his/her circumstances are.

The password has not been changed. No reports from a provider have been received with erroneous reports. such as account blocking. Not even for suspicious use of this. It's not an Internet problem. You can simply access the Internet.

you use Imap or Pop in the beginning when you started using these services. Can you have them set up like that. That unencrypted use of this may be possible.

The chance that you have been sending unencrypted messages on the internet for some time that you did not set up at the beginning of your registration. after several times unnoticed by you or has sometimes ignored a message that was sent to you during intensive use of the services.

And did this provider assume without notifying you that you once took the venture to message you sometime during that time.

Now without notifying you, it probably made adjustments on its end.

Now that these versions have actually been executed, you can simply change your port number and continue emailing.

So resetting your Imap encryption and the Smtp settings will override this.

content:
SMTP error from remote mail server after end of data:

Typical cause for this error is when the recipient's spam filter blocks emails sent by the sender. OR due to the configuration made on the SPF record that denies or adds specific domains to blocklists.

SMTP error 550 usually appears when there is an issue with the authentication of the SMTP client and the SMTP server.

Hence a valid comment posted by david to check smtp server.


550 High probability of spam Content in email triggers the server filter - for example by a link to a site that is often mentioned in spam.

You have managed to send an email with no links so this problem is not your IP address nor email address.

But is it any email with any link or just a microsoft teams link or just to a specific recipient?

Send a test email with a simple link to another website. Such as a link to this webpage: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1410612

Are you only getting rejections if the link is microsoft teams link?


I located some links that may provide some insight:

https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/msteams/forum/all/teams-webinar-invite-either-goes-to-spam-or-gets/c8890935-3de2-4b19-bbdb-207d47ce50bb

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/1045372/teams-invitation-emails-marked-as-spam

content:
Hi David,

Thank you! Yes, it _was_ threaded. I didn't know threading was on a per-folder mode. One more Question: Is there a way within Config Mode to _globally_ turnoff threading mode ? ?


Opinion below, for what it's worth:

I've really disliked threading-by-default from the get-go.

I've used T-bird for over 10 years and appreciate many of its features.

While making threading the default may seem like a good idea to some, it comes across to me as arrogant as the assumptions MSWord regularly makes about its user community. I really appreciate being informed about new capabilities, but Developers! Please query your loyal user community before making changes--especially defaulted changes--BY FIAT!

The above opinion also applies to the not-so-long-ago, misguided and rescinded decision to delete access to the system print spool interface. Thankfully the user community screamed bloody hell and that fiat was relatively short lived.

As I said previously, I've used T-bird for over 10 years and appreciate many of its features, but it is nowhere near being able to be used by the average not-so-technical feint-of-heart.

If the developer community is ever interested in creating an "ordinary user mode", I would be glad to contribute my list of current pet peeves and how I would hope a truly "ordinary user mode" might look like.

My best the readers and contributors of this support blog. Your work helps me continue my love/hate relationship with T-bird. I haven't given up yet.

My best to all of you! 'Till the next time. . . .
creator: jeffb4

content:
When threading was set as default, I complained a lot. That was then. I still don't like threading, but the fix is so easy that I no longer complain, but I share your opinion 100%. Yes, the developers shot themselves in the foot with that decision; however, the setting is in the config editor. Here is everything I know on the topic:

This is the official (to my knowledge) documentation. Well worth the read https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Here is my own documentation on threading, duplicating the above, but it may help: You need to highlight each folder and click View>sort by>unthreaded. If this applies to just a few folders, just repeat the process as necessary. If you have many folders or plan to add many new folders, you may wish a different approach, below:

More info: To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: 

    mailnews.default_view_flags      0       <=unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right. 

 ------------

To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: (I creates a crude video that walks through the steps at https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4 that demonstrates the following steps: 

  First, highlight a folder that you have set to unthreaded	   In the Message List view, in the column header, on the far right, open the options button that     shows  context menu. :   At the very bottom is the option:   -> "Apply current view to..."   -> "Folder and its children..."   -> Hover over an account   -> In the next menu don't select a folder. Instead select the account name itself.

ALSO, for future installations of Thunderbird, - install Thunderbird and exit prior to setting up accounts - create a simple text file with name of user.js with these lines: 

    // Set default threading to UNthreaded  ###   <== this line is optional, just for documentation     user_pref("mailnews.default_view_flags", 0);

- copy the user.js file into the profile - now, when you start Thunderbird, unthreading will be the default. Problem solved. (I have roughly a dozen config customizations, and by storing in a user.js file, I never need to redo them when reinstalling Thunderbird.)
creator: davidsk

content:
Thank you David!!!!!! Followed all your steps. What a relief (never would have figured out myself)!

I have an unrelated question at the end of my below-diatribe and am wondering whether we might have an off-line exchange, so I might formulate another question concisely for the T-bird blog so as not to take up too much bandwidth formulating the question.

I've been a T-bird user actually almost since it's inception (I'm that old :-)). At about version #63 when the major internal architectural changes occurred, I gave up on T-Bird and stayed with Version #62 (or so) until about three months ago. Why: I had a _stable_ email client that did exactly what I wanted! That is, I had a sufficient number of Add-On's that worked around bugs and that overcame T-bird deficiencies in my daily workflow.

I was forced to look at the current T-bird (>= #101) when I moved my mid-2012 Mac laptop to Open Core MacOS Monterey because T-bird #63 couldn't run reliably on Monterey. (Apple no longer provides "legal" updates to this hardware and Open Core makes it possible to run more current MacOS versions.).

What kept me with T-Bird over the years: • Easy viewing of email headers (mostly used for looking at scam email) • Add-ons that actually added useful features in my workflow • And sadly, in the majority: Add-ons that worked around T-bird bugs, some that had/have lingered for over a decade.

At least in the present version some of the decade-old bugs are gone. For example, I like putting blank lines between numbered list entries (using shift-return). Do this too many times and you couldn't get out of numbered list mde without standing on your head.

At least for now (please pardon my cynicism), the ratio of Add-On;s that do useful things to the add-ons that "fix" egregious persistent, decade-old bugs has markedly declined. I am hoping this trend will continue...

Possible off-line blog to help me formulate a question about message display/font-size/font display-----

The question(s) concern(s) getting plain-text and quoted plain text messages to display in Helvetica or Ariel font. I can be more specific with examples. (I dislike using Outlook, but switch to it when I have to, but would rather not.

Again, much appreciation for the pointers you provided. If you are intested and there is a non-public way to provide my email address, please let me know.

Again, with much appreciation. font in a fixed, consistent point size.
creator: jeffb4

content: I'm pleased that all is well. On your question, there are CSS entries for userContent file that can address color, bold or italic, and size for quoted text, but (to my knowledge) not font. The bigger question is whether any of that CSS will work with release 115, which is due mid-summer. Not knowing your bigger issue, your best bet to ensure visibility of quotes may be to use the quotecolor addon. And, font-related questions are always welcome here.
creator: davidsk

content:
I'm answering my own question here. The solution was...PATIENCE! I set the import going again and went to bed - came down this morning, and it had done it! (I'm not sure what "Importing...0%" was all about - it seemed to go straight from that to 'Finish'.)

So the answer is - if you have a large complex profile (like mine) - just have a bit of patience. :)
creator: JayceyF

content: To delete an SMTP server - click to account settings - scroll down left side to 'Outgoing Server (SMTP) and click to show list of servers - highlight the one to delete and click 'remove'
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks David, I didn't know that option was there on the left. It totally worked!
creator: JeffL

content: Kewl! You're most welcome.  :)
creator: davidsk

content: I know there are some who manage to share the same profile across multiple computers, but it's a delicate dance. If your accounts are IMAP, I suggest you take the easier route: - install/setup thunderbird on one computer - make backup of profile - install thunderbird on second computer - copy profile to second computer
creator: davidsk

content: As stated, I currently use a POP3 connection and have years of local mail which I wouldn't want to loose if the desktop went down. Introducing a different protocol, might work going forward but would not support access to the historical local emails. Is that correct? I wanted to keep this thread focused on the current POP3 situation. If POP3 cannot be resolved, then I would start a new thread on how to clean up from previous POP3 connection attempts and switch to a IMAP. Any suggestions on other support articles or how to proceed?
creator: laurencegregg

content: I think you will be okay by just copying the Mail folder between the two. Set up the second computer offline so that it does not download messages. Then exit thunderbird and copy the Mail folder in place and restart thunderbird. Each PC may have a different password, but the Mail folder is limited to messages.
creator: davidsk

content: Dave, I was able to manually configure the account offline and carefully reset all properties as they were on the desktop, except for the passwords. I shutdown and successfully replaced the Mail folder in the Laptop's profile. Thank you! That will handle the messages. Is there a way to identify the files that define the address books? I see three in the interface, Personal Address Book, Collected Addresses and One I imported from a file. Again, the intent is to have the laptop as a redundant device should the desktop go south.
creator: laurencegregg

content: I have had success in sharing addressbooks by copying and pasting all files beginning with abook and history.
creator: davidsk

content: I had a slight problem with that. In the Desktop's TB address books there 3 Books: Personal Address Book, AAA and 200 others, Collected Addresses. They contain 11, 201, and 16 contacts respectively. On the Desktop (and it's backup) there are the following abook* and history* files: abook, abook-1, history . Each have both an old .v3.sqlite suffix and a current .sqlite suffix. So that is 6 files in all. The 3 current .sqlite files were copied into the Laptop's Profile replacing the exiting abook.sqlite and history.sqlite as well as inserting the abook-1.sqlite. When the Laptop TB was launched it picked up the Personal Address Book, and Collected Addresses but was missing the 201 contacts imported into the Desktop called AAA and 200 others file. I did some sleuthing and saw that the prefs.js file did not have any ldap entries for the missing contacts from the "AAA and 200 others". I found the Desktop's entries in it's prefs.js and inserted those 4 lines for the abook-1 file into the laptop's prefs.js. Upon relaunching TB my missing contacts were found! If you have any problems with what I did please advise on what I should have done differently. If there is no other feedback I will mark this as solved. Thanks for your help!
creator: laurencegregg

content: Congratulations on figuring all that out!  :)
creator: davidsk
